title: Playing with Voices: Tabletop Role-Playing Game Recordings as a Diarization Challenge
author: Lian Remme (Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf), Kevin Tang (Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf)
relevance_why: This paper introduces a novel audio dataset from tabletop role-playing games for evaluating diarization systems. The insights on handling voice alterations can inform audio generation models in understanding dynamic vocal changes.
background: This study explores the unique challenges of diarization caused by players altering their voices during role-playing games, complicating speaker identification.
contribution: This paper introduces a new audio dataset from tabletop role-playing games to serve as a benchmark for diarization systems, achieving higher confusion rates than existing datasets like AMI and ICSI.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous diarization systems perform poorly in domains with overlapping speech and multiple speakers, as evidenced by traditional datasets.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages the inherent voice modifications in a playful context to create a rich challenge for existing diarization models.

key_innovation: Utilizes the unique linguistic properties of tabletop role-playing dialogues, where players might impersonate characters, increasing the complexity of speaker identification tasks.
real_world_impact: The findings could enhance speaker diarization technology applicable in various domains, including education, entertainment, and automated transcription services.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.diarization: **Diarization** is the process of identifying who spoke when in an audio recording, crucial for transcribing conversations involving multiple speakers.

open_sourcing: All scripts for data processing and analyses are publicly available on GitHub.
